data.title: Little bit of everybody
data.text:
We walked through after eating at L&J as you park at the cemetery to eat. Plenty of history pretty much anyone and everyone has passed through it to get to the west. We were losing daylight so it was hard to read a lot of the markers. 
Come by and then eat next door. That's a good night.

data.title: Real old history
data.text: Went to see the grave of John Wesley Hardin.  It was very interesting.  There are signs but are faded.  There is not shade or grass.  Reminds you of the old boot hills.  But exploring with a general sense  of direction you will enjoy surprises galore.

data.title: Easy to find, a lot of history here!
data.text: We did not explore the entire cemetery, and found the grave for John Wesley Hardin easily and quickly. There is a sign at the entry way which shows you where everything is. The "you are here" is a little hard to find, (it's at the top left side of the sign). From the sign you can travel easily about in your vehicle. There are separate sections for the Jewish, Chinese, Buffalo Soldiers, etc. I saw that some were lamenting the desert and dust but that's authentic El Paso. It wouldn't be normal to have green rolling hills out here. I appreciated being able to visit here and makes our obsession with the old west even more real! It is close to I-10 so you don't have to go far to visit if just passing through.

data.title: County burial site
data.text: Guess it is as good as anywhere to be entombed...when I am at that state it'll be fine to rest there. The probationers will clean the weeds out for community service.

data.title: going back in time
data.text: Concordia is one of the oldest cemeteries in El Paso. Many landmark El Pasoans are buried here. Gunslingers, badmen, madams, mayors, marshalls, soldiers and early El Paso political leaders are laid two rest here. Free. park along the street. Enjoy the stroll. History comes alive here.

data.title: Look a long way back!
data.text: From the pioneers, to the Chinese, gun fighters and buffalo soldiers , Mormons and Jews and so on, all lay there in peace! Look at the tombstones and try to imagine how it was to live at that time! Imagine tumbleweeds blown around from the wind......John Wesley Hardin  a famous gun fighter lays there and you'll find his grave fast! Take pictures but take' em in black and white you'll be surprised how they come out ( back in 1870)!

data.title: From Hardin to unknowns, a step backwards in history
data.text: A nice stop for visitors to El Paso.  Lots of tacky plastic flowers, tumbleweeds, dust, and tombstones with history. Walk around in the bright sunshine, then stumble over to the L & J for a tasty Mexican meal, queso fondido and hot tortillas, piping hot enchiladas and other dishes.  A great place to stop for your last meal--in El Paso.

data.title: Back to the old west
data.text: This looks as though you stepped back in time to the old west.  This really looks like the dusty end of the line, seemingly not much changed from the 1880's.  It just has not moved into the 21st century with the rest of the city.  It is enclosed within a stone wall, but one may walk or drive in to visit the grave sites.  It is just off Interstate 10, although not obvious to the passerby, but easy to get to.  If the old west intrigues you, this would be a recommended stop.

data.title: Hardin's Still There And Still Dead
data.text: Recently made a tour of dead Texas gunfighters, of which John Wesley Hardin was a highlight. His grave is very easy to find and if you look around you can see Diamond Dick too. One highlight is the area reserved for the buffalo soldiers. Well worth seeing.

data.title: Visiting Concordia is like visiting El Paso's history
data.text:
This cemetery has seen many famous and infamous people buried here. John Wesley Hardin's grave is a popular site. The new memorial to the Buffalo Soldiers is impressive. Unfortunately, much of Concordia is under maintained and much has had vandalism. In recent years, a greater attempt has been made to maintain what is there.

I enjoyed my visit to the various areas. I also ran into "Concordia Ranger" R.I. Antes who provided extra details and location information. As a historical Investigator, he is a wealth of information.

Overall, Concordia offers a look back at the people of El Paso and many who influenced El Paso's history.

owner_response.author: Melissa S, Public Relations Manager at Concordia Cemetery, responded to this review
owner_response.text:
Thank you, Paul L., for reviewing Concordia Cemetery. We at Concordia Heritage Association (CHA) always appreciates input from Visitors.  
We are an small group of Volunteers who look after,  preserve and protect the 52 acre Texas State Historic Cemetery, where over 60,000 people are buried.  Though it may look, to the uniformed, as a cemetery in disrepair. Folks must understand that we are a "High Desert Climate" which is very harsh especially in the summertime.  The only real green section of the cemetery is the Jewish Sections, which the local Synagogue's have perpetual care groups to help with the care of their Section.  Concordia is a mix of religious and private held graves. Historically the cemetery was never as lush and green throughout, as the Jewish section.  So we let folks know 1) we use reclaimed/purple water to help us nourish our Xeri-Scaping plants that are native to our Climate.  Ans 2) Using water to  artificially green the cemetery is only a waste of our limited water resources, as well as, affecting the character of the original cemetery which is more importantly a Archaeological Site.  Our Vandalism is down almost 90% since we added security, which eats up 90% of our budget, though.  Next time you are in our area, please contact Concordia Heritage Assoc an we can help you with a tue Historical Tour. concordiacemetery@gmail.com or visit our Website www.concordiacemetery.org or our Facebook page "Concordia Cemetery".
owner_response.title: Owner Response

data.title: Cool cemetery unfortunately not well cared for except the Jewish Section and one other section
data.text: So unfortunate the vandalism in this cemetery and the sad shape of some of the headstones - some by obvious poor craftmanship - feel sorry for the families who paid for headstone monuments that weren't properly kilned or just poor work . Someone should donate a big fund to get this beautiful and historic cemetery to make it look better. Also markers might be helpful for the historic headstones (maybe they were there but I did not see them)

data.title: Jo's much history here and the ghost tours are a must do!
data.text: Visiting here just to see the historical graves is interesting but the night time ghost tours add so much to the experience!

data.title: did not surpass boothill to us
data.text: we went here after reading reviews and someone said that they liked this cemetery better than boothill near Tombstone.  we were expecting quite a bit and left disappointed.  The cemetary is huge and the map boards at the entrances do not give you sufficient information.  There is a website as well with lots of info but as far as I could see no overall map that you can carry around with you.

owner_response.author: Melissa S, Public Relations Manager at Concordia Cemetery, responded to this review
owner_response.text: We, Concordia Heritage Assoc. do have a handout map that I can Email you. There are over 60,000 people buried in the 52 acre cemetery and we are working on interpretive signage, as found at the Veterans Section,  but we are a very small group of Volunteers that work hard to continue to protect and preserve the Cemetery, while  trying to improve the Education of the Public in general about the cemetery. Almost 90% of our budget/Money raised via Fundraising and Tax/Motel revenue  goes to Security, and since we added the security our vandalism is down 90%.  We are a High Desert Historic cemetery and we choose to Xryiscape our cemetery rather than plant grass. We utilize reclaimed water to water the plants/tree's throughout the cemetery. The Jewish sections Synagogues have Perpetual Care programs that is why there section looks so lush and green, which in reality is not the nature of our Climate. But, please do come back and visit us as we are working on a new program with a local Govt. Program to improve the signage and more improvements at Concordia Cemetery. Melissa - Vol PR for Concordia Heritage Assoc.
owner_response.title: Owner Response

data.title: Interesting place to visit
data.text: We came here after visiting the L & J cafe.  Our main goal was to visit the grave of the old gun slinger, John Wesley Hardin, but we enjoyed walking through looking at the other old graves.  Many are very beautiful and unique.  We actually got a mini-tour by one of the caretakers which was wonderful as well.

data.title: Interesting
data.text: We ventured to this cemetery to see the graves of the Buffalo Soldiers buried here.  It looks like a planned memorial to these famed riders is forthcoming, what is there now is a large bordered area.  Open to the public with structured viewing hours. Historical site that won't take long to tour.

data.title: Very friendly and helpful security/guard
data.text: I almost didn't make it there. I did not know that I was allowed to drive through it. Make sure you go there through the entrance/gate from the E Yandell Dr. (located in the middle of the fence/wall). There is a map of it (there is another one next to the gate on Boone Street but in a very bad shape). This map is not so easy to read and it is not very helpful to identify those more interesting (from the historical point of view) graves.. I was very lucky because the guard who was there at the time I got there was very helpful and he showed me what I needed to see and he told me a lot of interesting information about El Paso and this cemetery. I wish there are some brochures and/or better handouts for tourist to respectfully venture around graves on this cemetery. I was surprised that the cemetery was divided by religion and it look like that only the Jewish sector was taken care of! Why city won't invest some money in this treasure?

data.title: John Wesley Hardin and the wild, wild west.
data.text: I visited Concordia Cemetery because I wanted to visit the graves site of John Wesley Hardin, a gunslinger, who was shot and killed in El Paso, Tx. in 1895. This is a true "old west" cemetery that will take you back in time over a hundred years once you enter it's gates.  There is also a large section in the back of cemetery for the Chinese immigrants who built the intercontinental railroad. Most of the graves are marked with very humble and old wooden crosses, and the few concrete markers are crumbling away in most cases.  If you're into history especially old west history this is a must visit when in El Paso.  Wear comfortable clothes and shoes as the cemetery is 52 acres and will require some walking and hours if you were to visit all the sections of the cemetery.

data.title: Oct hours change
data.text: Be advised October 1 hours are 8-5 ONLY! Drove all the way there to find this out and was very disappointed.

owner_response.author: Melissa S, Public Relations Manager at Concordia Cemetery, responded to this review
owner_response.text:
Dear Marlene,
So sorry you got there and the cemetery was closed. The Cemetery is Open 365 Days a year from:
Winter 8:00 am to 5:00 pm
Summer: 7:00 am to 8:00 pm
The reason for early closure in October is for your Safety and Security. We cannot afford On site Security after 5:00 Pm in the winter hours. 
But, we do hope you will come back and visit us another time. Visit our Facebook "Concordia Cemetery" page to watch for special events, like our Ghost Tours, that help us raise funds to protect and preserve the cemetery. Melissa - PR Volunteer for Concordia Heritage Assoc.
owner_response.title: Owner Response

data.title: Concordia Cemetery - A slice of the Old and New West!
data.text:
I had the opportunity to visit the Concordia Cemetery while visiting El Paso this week and what an experience. From Outlaws and Gunfighters to Buffalo Soldiers and Civil War Vets,
this has them all. I have seen Boot Hill and several other Old West Cemeteries but Concordia Cemetery is the most interesting of them all. If you enjoy history of the old west, this is for you. Make a point to see the John Wesley Hardin site and the Civil War graves.

data.title: Grave and ghost
data.text: Very well labeled to find the famous graves.  Easy to get to and drive through.  Places to sit if you are walking.  I would not recommend walking this during the summer mid day.
